Reviews.Title: Update - Now has Amazon VOD Support
Reviews.Author: G. Peck
Reviews.Content: As many others have pointed out, this set has great picture quality. However, you will really have to work at it. Out of the box the picture looked awful and I was ready to return this set. Then I was lucky enough to find a review by "Gordon" for the Samsung UN32EH5000. I used the exact settings he specified and now the picture looks great. His settings are:Mode: DynamicBacklight: 18Contrast: 85Brightness: 50Sharpness: 80Color: 70TInt: G/R 50/50Standard color tone with screen fit in the additional options, with HDMI black level set to low.I just finished the latest software update and Amazon Video on Demand has finally been added!

Reviews.Title: The best LED-lit television at a budget price
Reviews.Author: Espy
Reviews.Content: Samsung's 2012 line of LCD televisions focuses primarily on switching their backlighting from CCFL to direct-array LED. Unlike CCFL lighting, LEDs don't diminish in brightness over time and have an incredibly long lifespan. Additionally, these sets are significantly lighter than their old CCFL counterparts which makes moving them around easier. However, this model is not edge-lit which means it's not really thinner despite the weight savings. The lights are directly behind the screen (i.e. direct-array), which many video purists prefer since it makes the lighting more even. This model does not support local dimming.Pros:1080pDirect array LED lightingDeep blacksBuilt-in WiFiVery lightweight3 HDMI ports2 USB ports (including 1 that has extra power for portable hard drives)Great DLNA support and file playback support (including 720p MKV files!)Keyboard and Mouse support via USBCons:Semi-glossy screenLackluster soundLack of swivel baseNo S-Video portU.I. is consistently clunkySome important settings are made obscureDisplayTo start off, the display is fantastic. Colors are rich and the blacks are deep. The set only supports 60hz, but I have never really found myself needing more than that. The lighting is mostly even, but there is noticeably dimming in the corners of the set. The screen is semi-glossy, which I dislike greatly because I can see reflections of myself or the room in darker scenes. Glare from windows is also pretty obvious, so definitely factor that in about where to put this set before you buy it. The bezel which actually makes it look smaller than it is for some reason. The controls for the set are a 4-way joystick hidden under the bottom right side of the bezel.SoundThe problem with thinner TVs is that sound suffers. My last LCD TV was a regular CCFL set and it had excellent sound. I am not an audiophile at all, but I can't find an audio setting I like for watching regular TV or movies. Either the dialogue is drowned out by music with heavy bass, or you can hear the dialogue (with added bass) and the music is barely audible. I fiddled around with a lot of settings and I just can't find one I like. After a few weeks I've gotten used to it, but for the first time ever I'm considering getting a stereo system to get "normal" sound back.ConnectivitySamsung has reduced the number of HDMI ports on their cheaper, no-frills models to encourage people to upgrade to their more expensive lines. The "dumb" models only have 2 HDMI ports, this one has 3. Additionally, it seems as though no models support S-Video any more, and this set integrates composite and component into one set of ports. There are two USB ports, one of which is labeled as the "hard drive" port because it supplies extra power. WiFi is built in, and I'm able to stream content from YouTube without stuttering or buffering. The TV can download and apply updates very easily, too. After the last update, file playback includes 720p MKV files, although options during playback are limited. DLNA support is fantastic, but refreshing of file lists doesn't work very well. The menu has settings that allow for mouse and keyboard control via USB, which is useful if you use searches a lot in the smart TV apps. It would be great if you could sign into Samsung's app site and click which ones you want to download rather than doing it from the TV. The interface in general is kind of clunky.OverallIt's a great buy. Lots of connectivity, access to smart apps (I enjoy the YouTube one, Netflix is also available and they are adding more). Definitely recommended.Tips and CaveatsIf you plan to use this as a monitor, make sure you label the source as "PC" of some kind. This removes a lot of post-processing. There is also a "Game Mode" under general that makes the display more responsive, but the downside to using this mode for me is that audio is stuck in "movie" mode which is very bass heavy.

Reviews.Title: Must change name of source to 'PC' if using as computer monitor
Reviews.Author: Phoney
Reviews.Content: I am using this as a large computer monitor, so the TV and Smart features are just an added bonus.  As soon as I got it unboxed, I plugged in the HDMI output from my late-model AMD 7850 video card, set it to 1920x1080, and was very disappointed with the picture quality.  It ran off the screen and everything looked fuzzy.  No amount of tweaking in the AMD control panel made any significant difference.  I was about to pack it up when I stumbled across a review here on Amazon where somebody briefly mentioned changing the source name.  He didn't say how, so I had to figure it out.  Just hit SOURCE on the remote, followed by TOOLS and then EDIT NAME on the menu.  Change the name to either "PC" or "PC-DVI" and the picture instantly clears up.  You get 1:1 pixel mapping and everything looks great!  This made such a huge difference I thought I would share since it didn't seem to be mentioned anywhere else.

Reviews.Title: Great TV, Software is just OK, Advice on getting Amazon Prime Video to Work
Reviews.Author: R. W. Cope II
Reviews.Content: The picture on this TV is great.  Even non HD content looks nice, and HD content is outstanding.  I give it three stars because, as of November 2012, the software requires some significant effort to get working completely, and that may not be for everyone.I bought this model not only for the great picture, but for its ability to connect to services like Netflix and Amazon Prime Video.  They work well, though they are bit slow to launch. Finding content using the remote that comes with this TV is a bit tedious.  I recommend using a computer to find what you want to watch on those services, and adding it to your queue.  Then you can launch the app on the TV, bring up your queue, and start watching more easily.The only snag for me in setting up the TV was getting the latest version of the Samsung software.  After connecting to internet (which was easy), the TV updated all the software, which took about 15 minutes.  Unfortunately, all the required updates were not available to the TV through its online update mechanism, and that caused the Amazon Prime Video software to fail to run.  It complained that the Samsung Smart Hub software needed to be updated, but the Smart Hub software reported that there were no updates to be found.Fortunately, a call to Amazon cleared up the problem.  They informed me that Samsung had an update on their website that I could download, load on a USB thumb drive, and install on the TV.  Doing that solved the problem.  If you have this problem, you can get the latest version of the Samsung firmware from their support pages (sorry, Amazon doesn't allow links to external websites in reviews).  Instructions on installing the update from a USB thumb drive are also available there.So bottom line, the TV is great.  The software is fiddly, and requires some hubbub to get updated properly.  If you are willing to work through that, however, the experience of using the TV is very good.

Reviews.Title: KEYBOARD AVAILABILITY
Reviews.Author: Jon J. Fields
Reviews.Content: SAMSUNG DOESN'T SEEM TO KNOW THIS, BUT YOU CAN OPERATE THIS TV WITH A KEYBOARD. PURCHASE A LOGITECH K-400 KEYBOARD, PLUG THE LITTLE USB ANTENNA INTO THE USB PORT, AND, IN SETTINGS, IDENTIFY THE KEYBOARD. IT WORKS PERFECTLY. THE KEYBOARD HAS A TRACKPAD THAT MOVES THE CURSER.PLAY WITH THIS AND YOU WILL FIND USING THE INTERNET ON YOUR TV A JOY.

Reviews.Title: First 5 rating for this TV
Reviews.Author: Seetha
Reviews.Content: I really love this TV. This is my first flat screen TV. I did a lot of homework before zeroing on this TV.I purchased it based on the following features: - It is a smart HDTV, LED  - 60Hz and this year's model available at considerably better price as compared to even last year models with similar features. Though, I would have been very happy if I could have closed the deal at $ 650 :-pI did see the earlier reviews for this TV but most seemed like user training issues.The sound/picture quality is excellent. Picture quality will seem dull with the eco friendly setting of Standard. However, it is configurable per your liking and the user manual is very effective in identifying and setting up your needs. 3 HDMI + 2 USB availableSetting up Network/WI FI is also very easy.Depending on Internet speed, the smart TV works good. Youtube videos does not stream so fast for me directly through the TV but when I connect to my laptop through HDMI, it just works fine.Movies through Netflix are great. No 3D but I did not want it. The LED TV comparison chart that Amazon provides is very helpful in determining what features you need and what you do not need.The Kids stories is very useful for my 3 yr old son. Recently saw our first 1080p HD movie "Journey to the center of the earth" and it was GREAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Movie files with .vob,.avi and .wmv works perfect. I have not tried others yet. Even, if some do not work, there are many sites where we have converters available. So this is not a big deal too.On the whole, it is a great TV with very good features. Its a good tradeoff between the basic models this year and the higher end versions which made it attractive for me. I did not have to settle for a lower less feature version nor wanted to go for umpteen number of features with a higher version costing above 1000 bucks.

Reviews.Title: Best in class LED TV esp. after you tweak settings
Reviews.Author: JB
Reviews.Content: I purchased two of these Samsung 32EH5300s over the holidays, and I am greatly impressed with them.  The "full-array" LED lighting makes the TV a bit deeper than the typical edge lit LED TV, but in return you get much more even lighting and an overall better viewing experience.  I was also surprised to see how good the Samsung does with standard def (SD) signals - of course not as good as HD quality but much better than the horrible quality I've seen on some LCD / LED TVs in the past.The three HDMI inputs is a must (sad to see so many other smaller TV now down to only two or even one HDMI input).  And of course the vast number of Smart TV features is great - I've already set up Netflix, YouTube, and HBO Go, while I continue to explore more offerings.One thing that I've found on all TVs including the Samsung is that the proper calibration / setup is essential to get the best picture.  I thought I'd provide some basic setup for TV / movie with this set from multiple opinions on the web; for more details search on sites like AVSForum:Set to Movie mode, then ...Backlight - set to 20Contrast - 96Brightness - 45Sharpness - 10Color - 49Tint - G46/R54Color Space - AutoWhite Balance - set gain to 17(R), 37(G), 12(B)Gamma - set to -1All enhancements (Dynamic Contrast, Black Tone, Flesh Tone, Motion Lighting, Noise Filter, LCD Motion Plus) set to Off or 0Color Tone - Warm 1

Reviews.Title: Great TV.. Must Buy
Reviews.Author: Krishnan R "Saxaphoneguy"
Reviews.Content: The TV is amazing. Retailers such as Best Buy, Walmart etc don't display this TV in their stores because they want you to buy the higher priced LED TVS... This TV is a well kept secret and has all the "next gen" features of a SMART HDTV.Without getting much into the technical details of the TV..1) Great Picture Quality... Samsung is the best in the business and lives up to it's reputation.2) Amazing surround sound.. you won't be disappointed3)High number of HDMI and USB ports.. You can plug in your Roku, DVD Player, Cable Set top box connection.. etc without needing an adapter to increase HDMI ports(4) Best of all.. I have lots of movies on my Portable USB Hard Drive, I plug it in the TV and *BOOM* I am able to watch ALL the movies from my USB Drive.. All popular formats supported including avi.(5) This TV has built in apps for Netflix, youtube etc... Roku.. Who needs Roku?? Sell it off in eBay and pocket the Money!The setup was easy.. piece of cake. Also, it's easy to install the TV stand (included with the TV) and get started right away. Buy this one compared to the other Smart TVs which Samsung sells.... You won't regret this purchase!!! (3D.. Who needs 3D?...Meh.. I surely will look stupid sitting in front of the TV with those ugly 3D glasses.. Still a long way to go for 3D to catch up)One small thing which I need to mention.. When I ordered the TV, the bezel was cracked below the SAMSUNG logo. I called amazon and they immediately arranged for a new TV to be delivered for free the NEXT DAY and my old TV got picked up from my apartment by the UPS guy..No hassle to drop it at UPS office, etc.. Amazon returns department is awesome.Go get this TV guys.. This TV is a hidden gem.

Reviews.Title: Samsung makes great TV's that are best in their class.
Reviews.Author: Christopher J. Cowen
Reviews.Content: Samsung makes great TV's that surpass every other manufacturer in their class.  I have this TV as well as another Samsung in my house and I can tell you the image is beautiful.  Now add in that this TV can directly connect to the internet and I'm sold.  TV's of this class have never been cheaper.One thing that I have found with TV's that its very important to actually look at the TV in person.  Now when you look at the TV's, go to a place like Walmart to see them, because many times specialty stores like Best Buy play with the lighting controls on the TV and in the store to skew the image to there advantage.  Once you look at the TV simply look and decide which one looks better to you.The next step is features:This Samsung comes with Auto Volume which automatically adjusts the volume of the desired channel, lowering the sound output when the modulation signal is high or raising the sound output when the modulation signal is low. This reduces the difference in volume when changing channels. The Auto Volume feature can be set to Normal, Night or Off.As far as outputs most of these TV's will come with more than enough Inputs and Outputs.  This TV comes with3x HDMI Audio/Video In, 1x Ethernet LAN In/Out, 1x RCA Component Audio/Video In amd 1x Digital CoaxialAudio Out.Next thing is in box technology:With this Smart HDTV there is a  full web browser with WiFi built-in apps made for TV.  Some of the apps this TV features is Hulu Plus, YouTube, Netflix, Facebook, and Twitter.  Browse the web while you watch movies and TV shows, and enjoy TV while you chat with friends and family online, all on one screen with this Samsung.Thank you for reading my review, if you have any questions feel free to email me, I would be happy to help you with any questions you have.

Reviews.Title: Audio Return Channel = Yes on HDMI2
Reviews.Author: Eric Mars
Reviews.Content: I bought the 5000 "dumb" version of this set about a year ago and have loved it. Needed one for another room & wanted Netflix / Amazon built in, so I got the smart version this time. Same beautiful picture. I also got the HW350 Samsung Audio Bar and scoured the internet for any documentation about ARC, which is needed to have full control of the SoundBar with the TV remote.As another owner stated in a comment, yes, it does have ARC on HDMI2, even though it is not marked or well documented. The sound on this set is pretty thin, and this inexpensive soundbar does make a huge difference, and is exactly the same width as the 32"er so it looks nice below it.So once you've got it connected by HDMI-ARC the next point of frustration is that the Soundbar will turn Off simulaneously with the set, but it doesn't turn back On with the TV remote's power button. There's a lot on the internet about this. Here's how you can turn it on with the remote:Hit "Tools"Hit "Anynet+"Hit "AV Receiver"Switch it to "On" and the Soundbar will turn on. (Note that when you set up Anynet+ from Menu you need to enable AV Receiver control.)So bottom line is you *can* pair this with the HW350 Soundbar, connect it via HDMI-ARC (on HDMI2 of the TV), and control On, Off, and Volume using only the 5300 Series remote.Hope this saves someone else a few hours of research :-)

Reviews.Title: How to make your smart hub connect to the internet
Reviews.Author: Jessica D.
Reviews.Content: OK, yesterday I would have given this 2 stars, but afters hours of googling on WHY my smart hub is not working it had a really simple fix. I spent 2 hours on the phone with samsung and they were really no help at all. So if you are having a issue with the smart hub not connecting to the internet you need to change your country code to whatever country it is that you are in. (I also changed the IP setting to manual and the put one 8 in each box) Then the smart hub will update and it will work!!!! I do not have cable and I bought the tv because I was tired of watching netflix on my laptop. The TV is beautiful, the quality is great and I got it for $599 on Amazon so it was a GREAT deal!!! So happy with my purchase now, thanks Amazon!!!

Reviews.Title: Nothing but issues with the Smart TV software
Reviews.Author: Surly German
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a Smart TV with Netflix, since we don't have cable.  This was one of the first smart TVs to have built-in wifi.  Samsung's products are usually at least decent, so we decided to go for this smart TV.  We bought it when it was first released and paid the hefty sum of $520 (it's now going for $328 on Amazon at the time of this review).  I have never been so disappointed with a purchase as I am with this TV.Samsung's smart TV software (Smart Hub) is incredibly buggy!  At first, the software would not remember our wifi password.  Every time we would turn on Smart Hub to watch Netflix, we would have to re-enter the network information.  Many times, we would re-enter the info, only to have the TV fail the mandatory network test.  All other devices in the house were properly connecting to wifi, just not this TV.  Turn off the TV and try again, you suggest?  Still wouldn't work.  There were many nights we turned the TV off in frustration after 20-30 minutes of fiddling with settings.After reading some of the other Amazon reviews, I took the advice of other reviewers and updated the Smart Hub software from Samsung's website.  The update process was simple enough.  I had hoped this would end my troubles with this TV.  It did not.  The TV remembers our wifi information now, but Netflix shows an error every time it is started, saying the app needs to be reinstalled.  After reinstalling the Netflix app, most videos get stuck at about the 30% mark when loading.  After about 5 minutes of looking at a stalled load screen, there is an error along the lines of, "We are having trouble playing this title right now."  Sometimes going back, trying to load another video (with the same loading issues), and then going back to the original video you wanted to watch will result in a successful play.  Other times not.I use Netflix on the Playstation 3, on my Android phone, and on the computer.  Netflix starts and plays video just fine on all of them.  The lowest common denominator is always this "smart" TV.  If I had waited 6 months, I could have gotten a traditional TV for hundreds less and a Chromecast for $35.  Then we would be able to watch Netflix without all the hassles of dealing with this dumb TV.  I would have saved money and my nerves.  However, I am stuck with a $500 paper weight.I could probably get $100 for this TV on Craigslist, but that would be cruel to the buyer.  I'm thinking it will be much more satisfying to take this damn thing out into the desert with my 12 gauge and go "Office Space" on it.  DO NOT BUY!

Reviews.Title: Great deal for a 40 inch!
Reviews.Author: PookieThePirate
Reviews.Content: UPDATED 11/27/13 - Check belowGood TV, just some minor problems.Well first of all the set up is easy and the stand is great.It just takes a few minutes to set up the internet, date, time, etc.What I first noticed was the picture and I didn't think it was that great UNTIL I MESSED WITH THE SETTINGS. I see a lot of people just rating it out of the box and you shouldn't do that. You need to mess with the settings and get the best out of this thing. So, I did just that and the picture was even better. Right now I just have analog television (well digital TV if you want to call it, no cable/satellite) and the quality is a bit ... blurry (not the TV's fault). But I expect movies from DVD's and whatnot to be better but that's another story (WHICH I HAVE UPDATED BELOW).The audio - out the box, it sucks. You need to mess with the settings again. Put it to stereo and some other settings I can't remember right now. I remember I could barely hear the audio even when it was on high. When I changed the settings, then it started to get more surround sound and more clear. There's A LOT of settings when coming to the audio, so that's a good thing. Right now it sounds like a movie theater in my house.The apps - There is a lot of bloatware. I don't know if I can delete some apps or not, I haven't tried. But for now there are some useless apps that I don't think I'd ever use. Amazon, Youtube, and Netflix works great. Also this is dependent on your internet connection. If you have a good connection, especially wired (I have wireless though), you should be fine. There were times where it froze for a few seconds, but that's because I was trying to do too much. This is like a computer and if you try to run too many things on a computer, that freezes too. So just be cautious.Web browser - Works but you need a wireless mouse and keyboard or else this is tedious.Regarding GLARE in bright environments - Well I live in a sunny place and I have sunlight coming in from the left side of the TV. So far I don't see a problem. Nothing is reflecting off of it. But I mean if the sun was right AT IT, I'd expect it to reflect. I don't think this screen is glossy, it's matte. Everything is fine on my side. Despite light coming from the side, it doesn't effect the picture quality or anything. I'm just speaking from a side view though.Summary :Picture - Mess with the settings to get the best out of this. Out of the box that isn't what it should be, because it doesn't look that great until you mess with it. I love Film/Warm 2 settings personally. But there's a setting for everyone.Audio - You DEFINITELY need to mess with the audio settings. It sounded so quiet with not a lot of bass at all until I tuned it up and now it's like a movie theater in my house.Apps - They work fine. Just don't try to do too many things at once or else there will be glitches, similar to computer freezes but it doesn't last long.Also for 400 bucks this is a great deal. I'm kind of bummed I bought this when it was 419, now it's 397! But before it was 442. Basically 2 weeks ago this TV was 442 and now it's 397. Just in time for black friday I guess.UPDATE 11/27/13 - Okay I messed with the settings and since I don't even have cable, I don't have a good stable connection for TV and because of that, it's blurry BUT NOT BECAUSE OF THE TV. I started to watch movies (Amazon prime HD) and they are AMAZING!!!!!I put the mode to Film, and the Picture Quality to Warm 2, It's like BluRay lite without actual bluray. The quality is amazing on this. I was watching Thor and everything was perfect.I saw someone on here say how Dynamic with high contrast and all that was the best and in my experience IT ISN'T. It burns my eyes. I love the subtle Film/Warm 2 look in my opinion. There is a "Cool" picture option but it makes everything too blue but when you get the settings you can mix it up, and there's A LOT of settings.I LOVE THIS TV!!!!!! I hope it lasts awhile.

Reviews.Title: HDTV with major glitches
Reviews.Author: M. K "Joe"
Reviews.Content: Got the TV couple of days back.Looks good but not a sleek design.It doesn't matter to me .The picture is great so is the sound.Got lot of options and features in this Smart TV.The price may be a little too much at this time, since it's a new model from Samsung.Apart from the price and the size(Like a LCD Tv because of its size)the TV is just amazing so far.Right now I'm using this TV only for streaming movies from VUDU and movies from my PC through the built in LAN.No buffering or whatsoever.Have loads of features,haven't explored all of the features.But navigating the remote is a real junk for web browsing.Flash doesn't work fully as described in the TV features.There was no sound in the site which i browsed using flash.Tried watchespn.com, but could not play the stream.So browsing the web and streaming videos is not entirely complete.Apart from these few glitches, TV is good.I forgot to mention one thing.My TV shut down a couple of times automatically on the first day, but after that no issues on that aspect so far.So it's not entirely great when compared to my LG set,which was really superb.Overall it comes down to a good(fair) TV with all loaded features.(This is  completely my view.Other's might differ)Update 04/01/2012:The Auto shut off was due to the settings in Eco Power saver.I changed the settings, after that no issues so far..I'm yet to figure out the Flash support on this TV..It's really difficult to browse using the supplied Standard remote.It has an Iphone app which i used for a while, it was slightly easier to browse.Will update on the full flash support in a day or two.BTW i could not stream(.mkv files from my PC)the manual says it supports .mkv, but so i could not stream it..Update:04/10/12I was resisting myself with updating the review hoping the TV will be free of any issues, but that was not to be.There are too many issues to list out.1.Random shut off issue.This occured again yesterday for, say 3 times...I'm not sure whether it is due to the surge protector i plugged into.2.Frequent Network disconnection issue while streaming from PC(both wired and wireless)3.When playing videos on youtube,it buffers or stutters with loss of audio after 5 mins...but other apps are working fine.4.My .mkv files are not playing.5.Flash is not supportedI had a chat with Samsung,i listed all the issues to the rep.He wanted to service in home..He also said Samsung TV's will not support flash and for all other issues the TV needs to be serviced.The product is not yet listed on their website and i cannot even schedule for repair.He offered to set up a service request on my behalf.I rejected and disconnected the chat.So there are many issues with this TV(it could be mine alone),ill wait for few more days before returning within the window.....Because of all these issues, i changed the title for this review.Update 04/11/2012I downloaded Samsung Allshare software from Samsung, UK, which has listed this model on their website and the .mkv files works well now,though the resolution is not 16:9.No Auto shut off today, so hopefully i'll stick with this TV....

Reviews.Title: Picture is fine.  The rest sucks.
Reviews.Author: denton
Reviews.Content: As the title says, the picture is fine.  Most of the rest of the unit sucks canal water.The user interface is abominable.  Boy Scouts using flashlights to send Morse Code are faster and more convenient.  In about 10-15 minutes, you can actually activate the Web Browser, manually enter a URL, and set up a new favorite.  I've ordered a gaming keypad that may alleviate this.  The supplied remote interface is user hostile.The ads say you can actually do email from your TV.  In theory, that seems to be correct.  In practice, not so much.  The Web Browser is slow, awkward, and clunky, not to mention extremely spartan.  If you're looking for decent browser features, you won't find them here.The Web Browser will not stream video from "unauthorized" sources.  It uniformly locks up at about the 20 minute mark.  I have plenty of wi-fi signal and typically 8-10 Mb download speed, and the same sources stream fine to my laptop on the same wi-fi connection.  Whether this is a bug or a deliberate feature to force you to buy Samsung's solution doesn't matter.  The bottom line is that I can't access the content that I want.Annoying Samsung partner advertising is impossible to remove.  Come on, guys.  It's my TV  I should get to pick and choose what I want on the screen.  A "minimize" feature would be nice.Before buying, I carefully went over the included features.  The ad shows Chrome as the browser. That would be a big plus.  But there is no Chrome, and no way to install it.  I tried activating one of the other features, and got a notice that it is being discontinued.  Look, if it's in the ad, it had better be in the box.  Anything else is false advertising.  You can't legally promise one thing and deliver another, which is what they did.I feel better now.  Thank you for reading.

Reviews.Title: Nice TV
Reviews.Author: Matt Lahm
Reviews.Content: I noticed a a lot of reviewers mentioned that Amazon video wasn't available on this TV.  I received my TV yesterday and it has an Amazon instant video app that loaded up after updating the Smart hub.  This TV also seems to support a wide range of video formats (.mpeg, .mkv, .divx, .asf etc.,) and has played every video I have streamed over from the computer.  My initial impression of having this TV is quite positive after 12 hours of ownership.  Upgrading from CRT technology makes this TV feel like a huge technological advance.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful Picture, Wonderfully Easy to Use
Reviews.Author: S. M. Schwartz
Reviews.Content: The first thing I was pleased with was the ease of set-up right out of the box.  I purchased this in combination with a Samsung WiFi Blu-ray Player.  The TV automatically went into the set-up wizard and was extremely easy to follow.The screen with all the icons panicked me at first, but it is extremely easy to maneuver through.  We have old fashioned (yet digital) antenna TV (yes, I know.... shocking it still exists), but the set-up found and locked in all the channels that the signal picks up - I didn't have to do a thing.  I set up my Netflix and Pandora accounts with ease and was thrilled that I can use my WiFi Blue-ray on other TV's and still download movies in my room since the TV has WiFi as well.Netflix streaming is flawless.  Super fast and no glitches.  I can easily switch from Netflix to DVD's to TV.  I have not played around with all the other options and icons on the TV, so I am unable to comment on the "SmartHub" part of the TV.The Picture quality is brilliant. This TV is located in a small room, so the 32" looks as gorgeous as the 50" does in the living room.  I currently do not have external speakers or a stereo hooked up and I am more than pleased with the sound coming right from the TV speakers.  Surround sound I'm sure would greatly improve the experience if you are watching action movies - but hey, we still have antenna's, what do you expect here....The quality WAY exceeds my expectations based on the price -- so I have to go big on the value of this purchase.  I would happily buy another Samsung product and recommend this one highly!!!

Reviews.Title: Random shut down and no flash support, bad Samsung customer service
Reviews.Author: GI
Reviews.Content: Update 4/9/12: Samsung service offered to service the TV finally; however, due to the size their is no on site service.  I would have had to take it to a place about 20 miles away from my house.  I finally have had enough of trying to debug Samsung TV issues.  I returned both of the 5300's that exhibited the exact same issues.  Hooray for Amazon return policies and ease of sending back defect products.SHAME ON SAMSUNG!----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Update 4/8/12:  Samsung service blamed my electrical in my house for ALL my issues (although they have never been here.) House is less than two years old, All other Samsung TVs that I have plugged in have NO issues (three other total).  I took the TV to another person's house and sure enough the same issues occurred.  So I guess If I call Samsung back the issue will be with the power delivery in a large metro area (I am sure customer service will continue to say there is no way this could be a Samsung issue.)Terrible TV and bad customer service for this issue!!!------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Update 4/6/12:  New issue seen, after the TV had been on for awhile maybe an hour, not sure if it had turned off/on or not as I had walked in and out of the room a few times; however, I couldn't do anything with the TV it was frozen and I couldn't even turn it off.  Had to unplug the unit to get it to reset and allow it to be turned off.It appears to me as if these TV have huge issues that need resolved before they will be ready to be used (i.e. I am seeing that others are having mutliple issues with different versions of the EH/ES TVs.)  I saw a similar shut off issue being stated on an ES6500.  I hope that a software update will fix these issues; however, I might have re-turned this Second TV with all the same issues by then.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------update:  Others have seen the shutoff issue as well.  there is a theory that it is related to ECO settings; however, the shut off should then only occur every 4 hours... But I turned off all eco friendly features and will see if the shutoff issue continues.________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________The TV is in HOME mode, in reference to the "user" error comment (this is not) as well that Samsung support can't determine the cause either...The TV picture is very nice and what you would expect for a lower priced LED TV.  Not the picture quality of the 8000 but a nice picture for the size and price.Pros:1.  All the bells and whistles of internet connections, netflix, apps, DLNA, etc... that I was wanting2.  Wireless capabiltiy INCLUDED with the TV :), haven't checked any ranges; however, I get a strong connection.3.  Pciture is nice4.  Easier setup to wireless5.  When surfing on the web page PIP comes up with the TV signal in the PIP (not sure if that was done for earlier revisions of the TVs)Meh:1.  Web pages have slightly better usability than the D series with a standard remote, not good, but qwerty keyboard comes up vs. using a phone style text entering.  This makes the process faster but still brutal.Cons:1.  The Web brower doesn't support Flash; however, I thought Samsung was supporting flash on these TVs. (bummer)2.  My TV, maybe not other 5300s, "randomly" turns off and on roughly every 30 - 45 minutes of use (still tracking and trying to determine potential causes), time other...A little debug on the shut off and other features1.  Further study suggests that with time on that the TVs smart features slow down and freeze (netflix) and when this occurs TV automatically shut off (so direct shut off with Netflix stutter and freeze)2.  Right after power cycled then netflix worked fine so it does point to the TV being the issue here and not netflixSoftware issue or hardware issue it is hard to say.Called Samsung support and they are wanting to service the TV, looks like it is time to return.With a swith out it will be interesting if this was a ONE off issue or a hardware/software/OS issue.

Reviews.Title: Amazing
Reviews.Author: TLC4urPC
Reviews.Content: Having researched and read all the comments about this TV i went ahead and bought it a month ago.very easy set up, found and connected to my wireless network right away and still no problems.I stream movies and shows from my server with ease and the speakers on this TV are amazingalthough i have my audio system set up i use the built in speakers, yes i think they are that good.All around this is a great TV.

Reviews.Title: The worst product I've ever purchased
Reviews.Author: AmazonDude82
Reviews.Content: What can I say? This is the worst product I've ever purchased in 31 years of consumerism. It's not broken. It's just an absolute piece of junk, and the designers/developers should be ashamed of themselves.I've been meaning to write this review for a long time, but today I just happened to be sick in bed...the perfect situation to enjoy my new SMART TV. Too bad it's the dumbest product possible and I've barely watched a thing in 4 hours. I'm fed up! I've had so many problems with it that writing this review is more fun than trying to get it to work correctly.Where do I begin? It barely loads the smart hub because it's way under-powered. The built-in wifi connects often enough to know that my signal is good, but it loses connection just often enough to call it unreliable. Of course there is no wifi status symbol anywhere, which is ridiculous since that's standard for every other wifi device on the market.Simple barriers to watching TV happen almost daily. When they happen, I find that restarting it works about 2/3 of the time, but often it'll get stuck in this unresponsive on/off loop where I have no idea if it's on or off. The annoying little "Power is Off" LED really gets my green goat. Why would they put a power-sucking LED on the thing to tell me it's OFF? Whomever thought of that should be beaten with a shoe, that's so stupid.When the smart hub finally does load, the epic number of bloat apps that come installed have to update. EVERY FREAKING TIME. Sometimes 3 or 4 times per day; something that I can't uninstall is updating. While I'm updating it tells me that I can watch TV from another source. Oh, really? Can I?I don't subscribe to cable because I'm not my parents, so I have a brand new accessory antennae installed. Of course this is useless because the Samsung Smart TV doesn't pick up any channels like all of our other TV's do. And forget having a channel scan function. It's nowhere to be found. I suppose I'll watch snow while I GUESS whether or not the update is complete. Yes, you heard right. There is a handy little update progress bar tucked into the upper-right corner when the updates begin, which is nice, but of course it disappears after a mere 3 seconds so you have to keep checking back in ever so often so see if updates are complete. It may not sound like much, but this stuff gets annoying really fast. Thanks, design team. You are amazing.Eventually the smart hub will log me in...yes, that's right: LOGS ME IN...to a mandatory online data-mining account of some type... I awkwardly fumble to navigate the chaos that is the remote / interface duo to find Netflix. When i say awkward...holy cow. It's horrifically un-customizable and looks like an off-band children's toy. It's truly an interface for the "don't" list, and the default sound it makes as I hit the up and down buttons...oh man. It pierces the soul. More on the crummy interface later.All I really wanted this thing for was Netflix, but after twelve unsuccessful loads, I finally cave and take the hubs advice to "reinstall the Netflix app". I navigate to the Samsung app store (which is basically a junk yard for storing countless redundant, buggy apps that you've never heard of and will never use) to find  Netflix at the tippy top. Of course when I click on the icon, I am greeted with a grayed-out "uninstall" button. Netflix comes packaged with the TV, so of course there are no admin privileges available. Great attention to detail, team: tell me to reinstall something then laugh in my face when I realize it's impossible. Guess I'll cross my fingers and continue trying to load it over and over.So I do. After fourteen tries (yes, I'm doing this as I type) it finally logs me in, but then Netflix tells me that it's having trouble playing my feature. None of them can be played...no idea whose fault that is, but it happens constantly on this TV and prettymuch never on any of  my PC's. It's worth mentioning that if I can get the Netflix app to actually work, anything high-res lags so bad it's unwatchable due to under-powered hardware.Sometimes when I'm fed up, I think...hey...maybe I'll give up on the movie and play around on the internet! Right. The built-in Samsung web browser renders everything just wrong enough to make browsing feel like a walk in the park with 4 broken limbs, and there are no external accessories available to allow the use of a normal mouse/keyboard (that I know of). You literally have to scroll using the remote and type in every letter, number, and symbol in by hand. Scrolling is skiing on rocks. Paired with random unresponsiveness and generally processor lag, typing in a basic search phrase is enough to make Rainbow Bright contemplate suicide. Stick to simple words like butt, boob, and bra and you'll be fine.Of course you'll have to surf with the lights on, because the backlit remote turns off after 4 seconds and it's so incredibly dim that my cat has trouble reading it. I guess they had to make up for that power off LED somehow.Should I keep going? How about the media server offerings! They're bad. Really, really bad.It has amazing plug and play support for Windows 7 Media Player, which seemed cool at first, but only if you want to control everything from the PC and have no playback control while watching a movie. No bathroom breaks without running upstairs first, sorry! Plus, who in their right mind uses Windows Media Player for anything?There is currently no NAS server support unless you have a bachelors degree in computer science + 5 years experience in kernal debugging. Samsung offers their own web-based client/server software to serve media from a shared drive, but there is no way to control it with the remote, it's laughably unstable, it takes forever to load, and it took me 3 days to get it working despite having a career in I.T. There are android apps available to perform basic remote control functions like navigation, volume, play, stop, etc, but they are all third party and few are compliant with Android Jelly Bean, which is by far the most popular version right now. I mean, how bad can you really drop a ball, Samsung?After days of back and forth trying out options, I did eventually get Serviio on Lubuntu to work fantastically as a media server, but how many consumers know linux?! And, despite my perfectly organized media folders, the TV still insists upon using obnoxiously presumptuous folder categories for everything. I have to remember where my files are being automatically categorized every time I try to find something. Why not just let me use the folder trees I meticulously created on the PC? Worst of all, I know they never intended to support anything linux despite the TV utilizing a unix-based OS. Some kind soul had to design and support a basic linux server app at his own expense just to allow people to use the basic functions of their TV's. It's a slap in the face of software devs and consumers alike. Samsung should be paying this guy his weight in gold for his service to society.The sad thing is, there's more. So much more. I just can't think of it right now. Other than the complaints, it's just an  average consumer-grade TV. the picture isn't particularly great, the sound isn't particularly great, the remote isn't particularly great, or anything like that. I will say that pluggin a usb expansion drive or flash drive makes playing media very easy. If you want to copy/paste all your media to a drive and bring it to the TV then you'll be quite happy, but in the age of cloud computing, I don't consider that to be very "smart". The other positive thing is that it was really easy to put together and it is unbelievably light weight; perhaps all the feathers inside are keeping it from working correctly.Overall, this is the most poorly-designed, disappointing piece of hype I've ever experienced. The whole point is to forego the use of a separate hardware to watch hosted media, but this contraption just makes it more tedious. The samsung developers did bad and they should feel bad.What I'm really wondering is how could anyone be happy with this product? It outrages me that this is an Amazon best-seller. Who are these people and when did they forget that products are supposed to actually function? Imagine if your refrigerator stopped you to update every time you wanted to make a sandwich. What if your car just stopped in the middle of the highway 3 times a day? Well, this is where we are heading if people keep purchasing this crap and giving it 4 stars./end rant

Reviews.Title: DO NOT BUY THIS TV; BUYER BEWARE
Reviews.Author: redact
Reviews.Content: I purchased this TV just a year and a few months ago and the power is out. The TV has a known defect with the power capacitors. They heat up and blow up. The cost to repair is more than the cost of the TV so this TV will probably end up in a landfill somewhere. This TV is junk, and I am furious I spent the money and less than a year (+2 months) later, the TV is blown. BUYER BEWARE. Samsung is currently settling a large class action lawsuit over this exact problem with the capacitors. See the following story in DailyTech at the following URL:[...]

Reviews.Title: Excellent choice - glad i got it
Reviews.Author: CarpeDiem
Reviews.Content: Just got it this morning and spent the whole day playing with it. It really is a fantastic set, with a lot of great features. The one concern I had was that the speakers would not be sufficient and would have to spend money on a sound bar. But that is not the case, they are pretty decent. Out the box, the picture levels are ok, but recommend making a few adjustments.I found the following settings on this review from another user, tried it and looks great, they are:Mode: DynamicBacklight: 18Contrast: 85Brightness: 50Sharpness: 80Color: 70TInt: G/R 50/50Standard color tone with screen fit in the additional options, with HDMI black level set to low.Well, so far so good. Also, really love the apps options. Noticed that today, i barely watched the cable box because of the amazing amount of content available thru the apps (from netflix, hbogo, vevo, amazon instant video, etc).

Reviews.Title: Great looking TV, read about the software and WiFI
Reviews.Author: dcg "dcg"
Reviews.Content: I own 4 Samsung TVs, clearly I like them.  They're reliable and work great.I bought this one for a tube-TV replacement in an RV.  I wanted something with built-in wifi and Netflix/Pandora/Amazon applications.  This one fit the bill.Got it home - looks like Samsung, works like Samsung..I had no problems connecting to my local wi-fi and running about 20 minutes of mandatory updates.  Unlike prior reviewers, I didn't have an issue with the Amazon app..Issues we've had so far:1) Using DHCP and Netflix, I had to use Google DNS (8.8.8.8).  This may be a Netflix-specific issue as we've had it happen on Apple devices after software updates.Here's the big issue for me:This TV doesn't talk directly to application providers.  That is, it doesn't fire up and talk directly to Netflix or Amazon.  It has to "call home" first to Samsung.  If that attempt to connect to Samsung fails for any reason, you get zero apps.We use this in an RV, so the wifi connectivity varies quite a bit.  When there is a connection problem, you're guaranteed a non-descriptive error.  Most people won't have this issue once it's up and working.It doesn't "ask" if you want to update.  It connects to Samsung and processes updates.  And it updates frequently.One surprise:I have a 1TB USB 3.0 drive that I have lots of media on.  This thing can read most of that media, short of divx... As such we didn't need a separate media player.Good TV, good price... I just wish the software wasn't so call-home dependent..

Reviews.Title: Smart hub ceases to work for long periods of time
Reviews.Author: Julio Bergonzi
Reviews.Content: Smart hub ceases to work for long periods of time. Most of the time when I try to open the smart hub and connect to the internet, it never does and then  the  TV turns off  and after a few seconds turns back on. To make things worse it keeps turning off and  on several times. Occasionally the smart hub opens but it does not recognize the wi-fi signal. I managed to go back to the original setting and it worked well fot a few hours then  it went back to  doing the same thing. I am very dissapointed.

Reviews.Title: A Samsung TV That Doesn't Look Stupid...32" SMART
Reviews.Author: MussSyke
Reviews.Content: My main TV - and thus my comparison point - is a Sony Bravia Z series from 2009.  Here are some things I think are outstanding about the Samsung.  I'll try to only talk about things that aren't mentioned constantly:1)  I dislike the overly contemporary look of most high-end Samsung TVs, and therefore don't usually consider them for purchase.  This, however, is a classic looking TV that won't look old next year and doesn't draw attention to itself at the expense of everything else.2)  Sony - and most other companies - no longer make a high end 32" model, which is stupid.  My main TV is most likely to have a local computer nearby.  It's the kitchen and the bedroom where I need the SMART features most.  For that reason, this TV actually has very little competition.3)  USB ports.  These are outstanding, especially if your network is too slow for streaming (or if you don't have a port nearby and your wireless is slow).  Where my older Sony only plays some pictures off USB - and way too slow to actually want to use that feature, this newer Samsung can play almost all my media files locally or use a wireless mouse/keyboard.  I have one USB port filled with a Logitech receiver, which allows me to use a mouse and keyboard I have stashed under the bed.  Haven't actually bothered to use those yet (except for testing), but it's nice to know I could turn them up and use them without having to mess with any options.  In the other USB port, I have a micro-SD card reader about the same size that always has 32GB of TV series that I can watch in a pinch, say if they put on some reality crap instead of a decent show that I was expecting over the air.  Neither USB device can be seen except from the side.  It reads the files on the micro-SD card directly from the source menu and as quickly as Windows Explorer.4)  DLNA.  As much as I love that micro-SD card USB reader, you really don't even need it because the DLNA features are pretty mature.  The fact that it reads .mkv files so easily, and you can control integrated subtitles and audio tracks so easily is amazing.  My other TV requires transcoding for anything but MPEG, which really bogs down the processor on my laptop.  I really recommend Wild Media Server because it works so well with both this and my Sony, and can easily spit 720p to both TVs (different shows) simultaneously.  I couldn't get Serviio or Mezzmo to work as well.  Samsung apparently has some freeware available that you might want to try as well.All that said, despite the high contrast ratio, I don't feel like the picture is quite as good as my older Sony (which I believe only has a CR of 100,000:1), even after a lot of playing around.  As you'd expect from its small size, it does play SD (and lower) very nicely on its screen without pixelization (Comment for 32" ONLY!).  Even so, I love this TV for the bedroom, and felt the price was reasonable.  It may get moved to replace the TV in the kitchen one day, and it will be great there, as well.Also, I would prefer a browser with adjustable transparency over the TV, as the PIP version has the sound and picture cutting out sometimes.  Even so, I would absolutely recommend this TV if you're looking for a 32"er.Oh, but one more thing:  I just had some apps "pushed" on me, like the cell phone companies do to your smart phone.  If this continues, I'll be lowering my rating.  I did not buy a TV to have a bunch of useless crap sold to me.  A warning to you, Samsung.

Reviews.Title: Nice TV with Some big flaws....
Reviews.Author: Jamie Shimizu
Reviews.Content: The picture quality is great, no complaints there. Colors are vibrant and sharp.There are some mind numbingly stupid issues with this TV though...No headphone Jack! The only way to use a headphone is the Audio out jack on the back of the TV. This has its own issues. It is hard to plug in, especially if you have the TV wall mounted. The audio will also play through both the headphones and speakers unless you use the mute button, or shutoff the external speakers (which is buried deep in the settings)Now here is the mind numbing part...the volume control does not work with the audio out/Headphones, and if you use the mute button, a big icon moves across the screen showing the mute is on, and YOU CANNOT SHUT IT OFF!I realize a lot of people do not use headphones with a TV, but if you do, do not buy this TV unless you have an external receiver that supports headphones.Smart TV:Works ok, but has some annoying issues. It is pretty glitchy- sometimes starts in a few seconds, sometime takes up to a minute.They layout is stupid and not customizable. The top has apps that like Hulu plus and Netflix, which cannot be removed. The middle is taken up by big windows for Stuff like "kids" "fitness" and Samsung's own movie rental/sales app. This leaves only the bottom for installed apps which cannot be arranged, and you will need to switch back and forth between pages if you have more than 6 apps installed.Also, this uses Samsung's own proprietary apps store (not android) so the apps are limited, although there is a pretty good selection and has most of the typical apps.If it weren't for some of these stupid little omissions and  design flaws, this would be a really nice TV.

Reviews.Title: Amazon Customer Service
Reviews.Author: SimFanatic
Reviews.Content: Others have written adequate reviews for which I can add little. Rather, this review is a comment on Amazon's customer service.I ordered my 46-inch Samsung UN46EH5300 late evening on a Tuesday, it arrived the following Friday. Unfortunately, the box was creased and the TV's screen had a 3-inch fracture (something like a spiderweb break). I got online immediately and followed Amazon's quite painless return/reorder process. Remarkably, when UPS arrived Monday to pickup the broken TV, they delivered the replacement at the same time.Trust me, I was not happy when the first TV arrived broken, but Amazon certainly went the extra distance in having my replacement delivered within two days.As for the TV I couldn't be happier. It was easy to setup and the Smart Hub is terrific.

Reviews.Title: Buyer Beware
Reviews.Author: sandra mcginnis
Reviews.Content: Received as 2013 x-mas gift.  As of 3-9-2014 Netflix and Amazon video apps no longer worked.  Huluplus worked only with repeated failure to play messages.  After 2hours on phone with Samsung tech support was told this model was manufactured using January 2012 software platform and will no longer interface with Amazon video etc.  Samsung is not currently supporting the software required to make these apps work on this model so this TV is in effect not usable as a smart TV.  Samsung personnel extremely rude to deal with.  Amazon on the other hand was very pleasant and efficient in issuing return tags and has promised account credit upon their receipt of this item.

Reviews.Title: Great set all around starting with the image quality and brightness
Reviews.Author: Pablo F. Fernicola
Reviews.Content: We got this set to replace an older LCD TV which was a bit smaller.  We are glad we did.Pros: The video quality is great, bright and vivid.  The audio has good volume.  The set is slim and light.I wasn't that enthusiastic about the smart features/apps before, but now I enjoy being able to access YouTube and Netflix with just  few clicks and the playback quality is great.I highly recommend this set.

Reviews.Title: Learn how to connect to disk network
Reviews.Author: KSH
Reviews.Content: We were able to connect to our wifi with no difficulty. The picture is fine. When we tried to connect to the dish network, which is wired in to our house, the tv would  not recognize the channel (channel 60 in our case) which has the tv picture. We ran the automatic channel finder many times using the CABLE option. Finally we called Samsung and they recommended runing the automatic channel finder using the AIR option. We did and it recognized channel 60 and now everything is working fine. We hope this will help you if you use DISK or DIRECT TV.

Reviews.Title: Up and running
Reviews.Author: SassySassy1
Reviews.Content: I think I love this TV. I just retired a 30 year old Panasonic (which still works just fine)  and replaced it with this Samsung. The set up was easy. I haven't played with all the internet / Smart Hub features yet, but the picture, sound and general set up are very good. I am hard of hearing and the sound on this is sufficient to overcome my deficiency, not to mention the set comes with CC built in.As to the internet / wifi - the set automatically sensed the network, asked for the password, and once that was entered and the necessary agreements in place, all the channels were in play, the wifi was up and running and here we are. The picture is great. This was worth waiting for. I had been waiting for a wifi, 32 inch TV since early last year.My only complaint, if you want to call it that, is the stand could be a little sturdier. It holds the TV fine, but it is not as stable as I think it should be.

Reviews.Title: DO NOT PURCHASE THIS TV!!!!!!!!!
Reviews.Author: lduarte999AThotmailcom
Reviews.Content: I WAS a fan of Samsung products. I own two tablets, an S4, an S3, an LCD TV and Blue Ray player. I purchased this TV and my perception of Samsung changed completely. The service and the quality of the products is deteriorating. The picture quality of this not the same as my old LCD Samsung by far. This device does not connect to the internet (via Wire or Wireless) and they already replaced it once. First the Samsung Tech told me he was going to replace the motherboard so I agree to it... and after waiting a while they said that they were going to replace the whole thing. At some point, the tech actually told me that it was working fine...I just needed to use an Ethernet cable going forward?!?!?! I told him that I wanted to use Wireless in a different room and he simply said: "just plug it in." He seemed to be bothered when I told him that I needed the Wireless option to work. I am not the type of person who types reviews but I am simply fed up with the lack of service and their inability to take ownership of the problem.

Reviews.Title: Great product.
Reviews.Author: Bayo
Reviews.Content: Just bought this tv and I am thoroughly impressed! It blows the 50" Panasonic Viera, that I have in my living room, away. The pictures are clearer and sharper. This is truly a high definition tv. I just watched the Michigan State/Boise game on the samsung, and it was awesome. The set up was so easy, all I had to do was to keep pressing the enter button. The internet connection is way better than other "smart" TVs I've seen. And the apps work very well. I tried the YouTube app and was impressed by the clarity. It only "buffered" once while watching a 5 minute video, and the buffering was just for 1-2 seconds. It also has way more apps than the Panasonic Viera.I bought this tv largely for it's features, including allshare/dlna. So, I was quite disappointed when I couldn't Stream pictures from my Samsung laptop to the tv because the allshare software doesn't support 64- bit windows 7 (according to Samsung support)...that's why i gave the product 4 stars instead of 5. However, I can still access music, videos and pictures through a USB connection. I will definitely recommend this product.============================================================================================================Update: I tried the allshare again with my Toshiba laptop which runs the same 64-bit Windows 7 OS as my Samsung laptop. Guess what? The streaming worked. I contacted Samsung again to troubleshoot the communication problem between a Samsung Laptop and a Samsung TV, but they just kept repeating the same line - allshare is not compatible with 64-bit Windows 7 OS. I pointed out that it was a stupid excuse and it doesn't make sense because it works perfectly with my Toshiba laptop which has the same OS. Samsung makes good products, but it's tech support is one of the worst because they don't know anything. You'd expect them to be experts in Samsung products, but all they do is tell you to reinstall the driver. I had the same problem when I bought my Samsung laptop a couple of months ago - the bluetooth streaming didn't work right the first time. I eventually diagnosed the problem myself (just like I did tonight). I finally found out what the problem was - my media player (not firewall) was restricting streaming to other devices.

Reviews.Title: Best TV so far - Samsung UN46EH5300
Reviews.Author: Debabrata
Reviews.Content: I used to be a big fan of Sony TV's including Sony Internet TVs. But after owning this TV - boy am I pleassantly surprised or what...this TV has everything except 3D - didn't need a 3D TV as 3D channels are hard to come by and personally I don't feel the thrill in playing 3D games with glasses ON - be it Active 3D or Passive 3D (Since 3D TV's are a misnomer and the actual effect is created by the software in the TV unlike in IMAX theatres where the 3D effect is created from the projector and the screen).Anyways, coming to back to the topic at hand - Samsung LED-LCD Smart HDTV have come a long way now in 2012. Samsung's SMART software is the dealbreaker in the market which has it all including AllShare which allows all format of files to be played including .MKVs, .AVIs, .WMVs, .MPGs, .VOBs, .FLVs etc and also plays videos, pictures from all kinds of input hardware like USB Flash Drive, HDMI and also wirelessly from the Windows/Mac laptops. This TV however has missed out on 16 Pin S-video input. Navigating the Web Browser is a bit of a sore with the Remote but with a wireless keyboard/mouse it works like a breeze. Apart from that the available apps have an awesome colection including default/in-built YouTube, NetFlix, Pandora, Amazon Instant Video, Hulu Plus - not to mention the Skype, Vudu HD Movies, Red Karaoke etc. The app collection is the best than any competitive Smart TV app collection including many free and paid downloadable apps.Moving onto the best part - the picture quality. This 1080p TV although may not boast of high motion frequency of above 120Hz (CMR) but the color depth and crispness is one of the best in the market comparable to any TV at any price point. This LED LCD TV is not Edge Lit instead it Back Lit with full array of LED and hence the color contrast really brings the HD shows to life with black levels which are as good as any Plasma TV without any clouding at edges. The only issue is picture formats have only 4 formats like Standard, Movie, Clear but has no Game setting.Next comes the sound quality...many other reviews have cribbed over the poor sound quality..but personally I have found them good though not good enough to blow you away as it is a bit Bass heavy. However, for my taste and requirements it meets my purpose but may be not for many - in that case would suggest an external sound system.To sum it up I have been using this TV for last 3 weeks with no issues at all. The only pain in the neck was setting up the TV on its stand. I personally would suggest a 46" TV to be wall mounted rather than on a stand.

Reviews.Title: First Samsung Television
Reviews.Author: Marvin B. Roffman
Reviews.Content: I purchased this Smart Television site unseen because of the width of the unit at 29.1".  I wanted a 32" screen but in almost every competing set the width of the set would have forced me to remove the doors of a cabinet that would house the unit.  This Samsung was the exception.  Now that I have the set I'm very pleased that I purchased it.  First off the picture quality is outstanding.  I love the fact that it is a smart tv which was a breeze to set up.  Now a little help for all who have this particular tv.  I purchased a Logetech K400 wireless keyboard which allows me to input text using quackery for a fast way to communicate on the internet.  Works like a charm and I purchased the keyboard at Staples for less than $30.

Reviews.Title: Incredible Value
Reviews.Author: CardinalDoc
Reviews.Content: I was skeptical about buying this television because of some negative reviews, but went ahead and pulled the trigger because of Amazon's great return policy.  So far (three weeks) I have nothing but great things to say about this TV.  It arrived in great shape and I have not had a single problem thus far. At under $900, the picture quality and features make this a tremendous value.

Reviews.Title: I loved this TV for about 3 weeks, now it's way over priced for a basic TV
Reviews.Author: Tina Pruett
Reviews.Content: I purchased the 32in model for our bedroom on cyber Monday (2013). For the first 3 weeks it was great. the picture quality is nice, the sound is decent for a bedroom set without any external speakers... however the main reason I purchased a smart TV was to watch Netflix and amazon instant video.In early January I started getting a Netflix error message on every single video that says, "we're having trouble playing this title now, please try again later." Except that message has not gone away for over 3 months. I have tried different things to fix it:- resetting (and reinstalling) the smart hub countless times- deactivating and logging into netflix repeatedly- switching the TV country to the UK and other foreign countries (and back to the US again)- changing network settings on my router and modem..I've probably been spent a cumulative 10+ hours on the phone trying to fix this issue. I've worked with remote management 5 times, tier 2 support, Netflix support... I've been told it would be fixed within 24 hours, then 48 hours, another time it was a week, another time two weeks... Netflix blames Samsung, Samsung blames Netflix..My Netflix works on EVERY other device, including my Samsung phone, Samsung Note 10.1 tablet, Samsung blueray player, Macbook pro, etc... so clearly it is this TV specifically that is not working. I have 6 different Samsung support transaction numbers, and I've talked to no less than 20 different Samsung employees.Samsung has told me the issue is:- a netflix server outage- a netflix application error- a netflix server update that is not compatible with the current version of the netflix app- a conflict on the netflix server because I access netflix on other Samsung devices from the same ISPNetflix has suggested that Samsung has over-produced SmartTVs and double issued the Netflix ESN numbers to different customers, causing the netflix servers to reject both TVs....As of today, I am waiting for a call back from the Executive Customer Relations department. I've asked to have Samsung replace this TV with a working model. Who knows where that will go, but I am sick and tired of having spent the extra money on a smart TV to not get a smart TV. I could have bought a larger HD TV without the SmartTV aps for the same money, or saved myself some cash and gotten a normal HDTV...I wish I hadn't trusted the numerous customer service agents who told me this would be fixed within a few days/weeks while I still had time to return the TV and replace with with something else...

Reviews.Title: Smarthub is too buggy.
Reviews.Author: Jonathan
Reviews.Content: The main reason people would buy a television with integrated app support would be to use said television to watch streaming video via the most popular streaming video service in the U.S., Netflix or maybe Amazon Prime Instant Video (hey, it's free w/ prime). I'm sure there are some Hulu people out there somewhere in the world too.Well, the SmartHub, the software inside your TV that lets you download and use apps, like the netflix app, etc., has become increasingly buggy since I set up my TV.See ongoing discussion on C-Net: [...]More recent discussion on Uno Telly: [...]Problems:1. Constant updates. The TV demands that I reinstall or update the Smarthub software almost every time I turn the damn thing on. I don't have cable. I bought this TV for the sole purpose of using the Smarthub to stream content online. Every day when I get home from work and put my feet up to watch some House of Cards or something, I have to sit through a 10-minute update. Frequently, these updates reset the passwords on my streaming service account so I have to enter those again, using a TV remote mind you. Needless to say this is annoying after the 2nd or 3rd time, but it's infuriating when you have over 10 updates in less than a month.2. Netflix and Amazon Instant Video constantly unusable. Netflix works on my Android mobile device. It works on my roommate's Xbox. It works on my PC and it works on my laptop. I've never had a single error message on any of these devices in the 2 years I've been using Netflix. Not one. Guess what device Netflix almost never works on. My Samsung smart TV. The sole reason I bought this TV was to watch streaming content over Netflix, and I get an error message about 9 out of the 10 times I try to use it. Restarting the app or the smarthub usually does not work. Reinstalling them doesn't either. I've call Samsung customer service and their official stance is that this is Netflix's fault and Amazon's fault, and, amazingly, not a breach of warranty. I paid hundreds of dollars for a TV that's supposed to do one thing. It fails at that one thing. And it's not Samsung's fault. Amazing. I'm seriously considering a class action against Samsung for this BS product.3. Sound quality is poor. I have to blast the volume in order to understand what people are saying. I sit 9 feet from the screen. The words hit my ears with the clarity an AM radio station. I'm a 29 year old male so I don't think my hearing is fading yet, just generally mushy sound. I set the TV sound to "clear dialogue" mode which did absolutely nothing.I gave 2 stars because the picture quality is satisfactory.Don't buy a smart TV from Samsung. You're better off just buying one of their regular TV's and spending $100 on an old xbox 360 for the same functionality.

Reviews.Title: Possibly the worst TV ever made
Reviews.Author: lmw
Reviews.Content: My 4 year old Sony Bravia decided to give up the ghost immediately following game 1 of the 2013 World Series. So I was forced to go out and buy a TV quickly and without much research.  I purchased this Samsung model from a local Target store, along with their 3 year protection plan.For a few weeks the TV seemed to work ok.  The picture is no worse than most major brands but still not as good as Sony TVs. The sound quality seems fine.The issue is the functionality and reliabilty of the SmartHub feature.  I have the TV connected to the internet using an ethernet cable. I am not using the WiFi that is built in to the TV.Since getting this TV in October, it has had to update it's software at least once per week, sometimes more often, this process is not quick despite my internet connecting being well higher than is needed for media streaming.  Curiously, when I navigate to the Software Update section in the Menu, I get an error message that says "This function is not available."  Really?About every 3rd time I turn it on and press the remote button to launch SmartHub, it crashes and will not start until I turn off the TV and turn it back on.About every 3rd time I try to launch Hulu or Amazon, the app itself crashes and I have to exit out of it and relaunch. Sometimes this does not fix it and the whole TV has to be turned off and back on.About every 10th time I try to launch SmartHub, it tells me there is no internet connection.  Yes there is. Every other internet device in the house is working just fine thank you.  Again, must turn off TV and back on, sometimes this doesn't work and I must actually unplug the TV wait a bit and plug it back in.At least 3 times since October, when launching Hulu or Amazon, a message pops up saying the clock is not set and needs to be set in order to use the SmartHub services. I go to the menu and to the clock setting to find it is actually set to the right time. The only way out of this loop is to change the time, exit, go back in and reset it to the correct time.As I type this I'm currently stuck in a new error message loop of "No internet connection" and "Clock not set" messages. No amount of relaunching, resetting, restarting, rebooting is working.  I am completely unable to launch any of the SmartHub apps at this time and after they try to launch for a few seconds the screen goes completely black. ... UPDATE: A few hours after first posting this review I was finally able to get SmartHub to launch but it took unplugging the power and ethernet several times.  Then today there's yet another SmartHub software update and now Amazon Prime will launch but Hulu will not.  Sigh...I should have spent the extra money on a new Sony... at least it may have lasted 3 years instead of 3 months.  It really ticks me off that the majority of Amazon Prime ready TVs are Samsung products, there are very few others to choose from and most of those are either giant 50+ inch screens or they are only available used or refurbished.After writing this review, I spoke with the manager of the store where I purchased the TV and the extended warrenty department.  The store will not help me.  It is 3 weeks past the 60 return period so they will not give me a refund or exchange.  The warrenty department said since the TV is within the first 12 months, they cannot help me either until the TV is one year old, then the extended warrenty will kick in.  I have no choice but to go through Samsung directly and based on the comments made by others on their experience dealing with Samsung I do not even think it's worth the time and stress.  I basically have a $450 piece of Samsung junk.

Reviews.Title: Considering getting a Roku for this "Smart" TV
Reviews.Author: Kevin D. Peterson
Reviews.Content: I regret getting rid of my Roku before I had lived with the "smart" tv for a while. Yes, it has Netflix and Amazon, but the whole experience of using them is miserable:1. The TV always boots up to "dumb" mode and you must push the button for Smart Hub, which takes about 30 seconds to load.2. It doesn't have any memory of what you used last, so now I have to select Netflix (apparently, my TV thinks I should exercise more because it always starts up on "Fitness")3. The Netflix and Amazon apps are painfully bad compared to a Roku. They're slow to load, the responsiveness is slow, and they randomly freeze up.4. The Smart Hub has updated itself about 10 times in the three weeks I've had the TV.5. There are about a dozen different apps taking up screen real estate for the sole purpose of selling you content, like Your Video, Fitness and Kids.6. Nothing is integrated. Every app has a different one-screen keyboard, none of them can make use of a USB keyboard (although the TV itself can for a few things). Every app has a completely different UI.If I hadn't given my Roku away with the CRT TV I replaced I would have just hooked it up. The whole Samsung experience feels like trying to navigate a web site filled with ads where every click takes you to a popup.Ignoring the smart TV features, this is a pretty good TV. The picture, sound, build quality, and remote are all what I expected. It is slow to switch channels, but that seems to be common now that everything's digital.

Reviews.Title: Bad Samsung
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Two weeks after the return window expired, this unit stopped working as advertised.  Samsung refuses to do anything but go through reset steps over the phone.  This is the second time this has happened to me with a Samsung TV product.  Honestly, I should have known better but thought I would give Samsung another chance...my mistake.Update: Since the Samsung doesn't work, I had to go out and buy a roku.  It streams every thing the Samsung fails at brilliantly and so much more.  So the issue is definitely with the Samsung product, and not my network, as Samsung insisted it was.My recommendation would be to purchase a less expensive TV and add the Roku for streaming.  It's much smarter than the samsung smart tv.

Reviews.Title: A great TV
Reviews.Author: DM3147 "DM3147"
Reviews.Content: This is one of a number of Samsung flat screen TVs that I have owned over the past couple of years (including a recent 3D version of this same TV) ... and as a LED HDTV, probably the best quality to date. I particularly like the "SmartTV" feature and all the applications available once it is connected to the internet.  This whole "smart TV/internet capable" feature available on current TVs is definitely a leap forward.  One feature that was pointed out by a sales person selling me a blu-ray player, was that by buying a different brand blu-ray player than the TV, you are expanding the built-in applications available ... So I paired up this Samsung flat screen with a Sony blu-ray player and have more built-in applications than I know what to do with ... including access to Amazon Prime, which gives you select movie streaming for free.

Reviews.Title: It is not smart enough yet
Reviews.Author: Sanju
Reviews.Content: The TV is good as far as all the TV parameters are concerned. But this review is about the smart part of it.Most of the apps works well, especially the netflix.Youtube app also works well, but lacks the movies interface that is available on the PCs. So I tried the browser for youtube movies. It was the quite a disappointment. The movies start well and then at some point just stops playing.Skype works only if you buy an expensive camera to go with TV.And whenever the samsung server is down, the TV can not access any content from internet. This is the biggest issue. I can not even use the browser when this happens.

Reviews.Title: Review of Samsung UN32EH5300
Reviews.Author: Ken
Reviews.Content: I've had this television up and running for about a week now, and am very happy with my purchase. The picture is excellent and allows for detailed tweaking through the menus. The compact frame around the screen works well to give me the maximum picture size in the limited space of my bedroom.The wireless internet setup was a breeze, and I have not experienced any connection hang ups to date. I agree that navigating on the internet on this television using the remote is very clunky and not worth the effort. However, the primary apps that I use (NetFlix, Hulu Plus, Pandora) through this set work well as expected. Also, I am relieved to not have experienced the automatic shut-off problem that another reviewer posted.

Reviews.Title: TV reboots unexpectedly (UN40EH5300 delivered August 2013)
Reviews.Author: Trace W
